Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2016 ACM Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking (ACM MobiCom)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ACM MobiCom conference is the leading international conference focusing on systems issues in the emerging area of mobile computing and wireless communications. The topics addressed by MobiCom 2016 are at the core of the current wireless network evolution. The conference attracts research contributions spanning multiple disciplines, including wireless networking, vehicular communications, personal area networks, ad hoc networks, operating systems, distributed algorithms, data processing, scheduling, sensors, and signal processing. In addition to the main session, the conference also provides good opportunities to students and researchers to participate in panels, workshops and demos that bring in brilliant ideas and applications in mobile, wireless and ad hoc networking and computing.

The NSF travel grant program will help increase representation and participation of United States-based graduate and undergraduate students at this conference, and enable sharing of information and preliminary research results among participating students. Participation of top conferences like ACM MobiCom is an extremely important part of the graduate school experience, providing students with an opportunity to interact with more senior researchers, and exposing them to leading edge research in the field. The award will enable graduate students who would be otherwise unable, to attend the main MobiCom 2016 and the associated workshops.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Binghamton
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Twenty-three students including women and minority groups were awarded the travel grant for attending the 2016 International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking (MobiCom 2016) in New York, NY, U.S. The travel grant covered their partial expense of conference registration fees, lodging, and meals in New York. The students engaged in a variety of conference activities including presenting their research results to their peers in the computer science, participating the student research competition and the mobile app competition. In addition, all the students contribute to the conference as volunteers, which provide great opportunities for the students to be closely involved in interactions between researchers from all over the world. The participation of the rich program of the MobiCom 2016 and associated workshops exposed the students to new ideas and cutting-edge research in the computer science.

A total of 51 students from 32 universities applied for the travel grant. 23 students were selected based on the selection criteria described in the proposal. Three out of four female applicants are selected to be awarded based on the selection criteria described in the proposal. Eight out of the twenty-three students (i.e. 35%) awardees are junior Ph.D. students with one- or two-year experience. The participation of the graduate students has a great impact in shaping their careers, including identifying and/or sharpening their career goals during discussions with their peers, or discovering their role models among senior researchers that they will have met at the conference or increasing opportunities for their collaborations and their breadth of ideas and technical perspectives.
